{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3585474,"name":"","username":"Dex999999999","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dex999999999/{size}/209038_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-09T18:21:59.875Z","cooked":"

I want to align with the barge but need to allow the driver to control the horizontal movement for once the barge starts getting full. This could be helped by either pathfinding to a point on that line or roughly lining up before and having path planner only choose the closest point on that line?

One idea that we haven’t decided wether to implement or not, is we split the barge into 6 segments. The bot would line up to whatever segment it’s closest too. This, however, doesn’t give you full horizontal movement flexibility for the driver.

make a method to find the target when you press a button, when the button is pressed it takes the current x (or y depends on your coordinate system) and then the specified y (dist from barge) and have your robot follow a drive vector pointed toward the target position (so for example if your robot is at -80, 140, and you wanna be at y = 60 make the target pose -80, 60), and use a PID or Trapezoidal Controller to follow and stop at the point and score when you reach the dest.

PID would be a very simple way to implement this, my team uses PID for our auto-align

this does also assume you have decent odometry and vision pose estimation to get these global coordinates

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-04-09T19:00:13.547Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":142,"readers_count":141,"score":73.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":498600,"topic_slug":"pathfind-to-nearest-point-on-a-line","display_username":"Kade Rabe","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52484,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 3082 - Programmer/Driver"},"post_url":"/t/pathfind-to-nearest-point-on-a-line/498600/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3585893,"name":"Nehuel Armenanzas","username":"uncookednehuel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/uncookednehuel/{size}/167476_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T01:08:17.124Z","cooked":"

We implemented something that is almost exactly what you are describing! However we removed it now since the driver wanted something different.

Here are some pointers to how we did it:

  • To find the closest point on a line, we used Inigo Quilez’s SDF (signed distance function) derivation for a line segment primitive, found here. That original implementation is in GLSL, and gives you the distance to the closest point on that line. However, you may notice the final operation in that function gets the length of a vector. To get the vector from the closest point to the robot pose, just use the vector that is inside that length function.
  • Make sure to negate the vector, since it is originally from line segment point to robot, and then add it to the robot’s field pose to get the final field coordinate of the closest point
  • Then, we made an drive command that drove the robot to a pose using a ProfiledPIDController to drive the X and Y coordinates of the robot to a position (we later improved this by making it driven by polar coordinates, but that’s something of its own). To accommodate horizontal movement for the driver, we allow the Y position of the pose it is aligning towards to be modified based on the same function we use to calculate Y velocity of the drivetrain. We just take that calculated velocity from the controller class and multiply it by the period (2ms, or 0.02 seconds) to get the goal position for the next loop.
  • If you desire to align to a diagonal line segment, like for the coral station, instead of changing only the Y coordinate, add the vector made by: the vector of the line segment (point2 - point1), normalized, and multiplied by the strafe speed.

Here is our file with the line segment primitive implementation:

github.com

frc78/2025-robot/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/lib/GeometryPrimitives.kt

package frc.robot.lib

import edu.wpi.first.math.MathUtil
import edu.wpi.first.math.Vector
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Translation2d
import edu.wpi.first.math.numbers.N2
import frc.robot.lib.FieldGeometry.FIELD_X_LENGTH
import frc.robot.lib.FieldGeometry.FIELD_Y_LENGTH
import kotlin.math.abs
import kotlin.math.hypot

abstract class Primitive {
    /** Returns vector from the closest point of primitive to the input position */
    abstract fun getVectorFromClosestPoint(position: Translation2d): Translation2d

    /** Gets the shortest distance to the primitive */
    abstract fun getShortestDistance(position: Translation2d): Double
}

class LineSegment(val p1: Translation2d, val p2: Translation2d) : Primitive() {

If you want something pretty simple you could just use PID on your X coordinate and then pipe through the usual driver control for the Y axis. I’m not sure if this is what you want as this couldn’t pathing around say, the reef, but if you’re only activating it close to the barge that wouldn’t be necessary. Here’s a little more complex example of this we use for the reef:

github.com

FRC2539/javabot-2025/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/commands/AlignToReef.java

package frc.robot.commands;

import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.PIDController;

import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Rotation2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Transform2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.ChassisSpeeds;

import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.Command;
import frc.robot.subsystems.swerve.CommandSwerveDrivetrain;
import java.util.function.DoubleSupplier;
import org.littletonrobotics.junction.Logger;

public class AlignToReef extends Command {
    private CommandSwerveDrivetrain drivetrain;

    private DoubleSupplier xVelocity;

The “lines” we are lining up to in this example are perpendicular to the reef faces.

setpoint","slug":"yagsl-swerve-jitters-to-heading-setpoint","posts_count":2,"reply_count":0,"highest_post_number":2,"image_url":null,"created_at":"2025-01-11T17:54:34.250Z","last_posted_at":"2025-01-11T22:02:47.339Z","bumped":true,"bumped_at":"2025-01-11T22:02:47.339Z","archetype":"regular","unseen":false,"pinned":false,"unpinned":null,"excerpt":"Our
